transcript.text: Luke and Tom here with the outdoor boys

fire starters we're going to show you
some fire safety tips and I'm going to
teach you how to build a one-match fire
in any type of weather condition they're
going to be tips and tricks for both the
beginner and the season to outdoorsmen
well I'm probably the best place you
could ever imagine for gathering
campfire wood so with that let me talk
to you about the three types of campfire
wood there's tinder kindling and fuel
okay tinder is the small stuff it's the
little fine stuff that you light without
right after you light your match the
kindling is the medium-sized stuff that
you use to grow your fire to the desired
size and the stuff I call fuel is the
big stuff it's the logs that you use to
maintain the fire keep it going by far
the most common rookie mistake when
building a campfire is not gathering
enough wood when you light that match
you want to have everything you need
right there ready to go you don't want
to have to leave your fire unattended to
run off into the woods and find more
wood so get everything ready get it
ready to go then light your match in
order to know how much wood you're going
to need for your campfire here's some
things that you should know an average
normal campfire typically burns about
four to six logs at any given time
additionally a log you lose is about one
inch of radius for every hour of burning
alright so let me give you an example
this log is three inches across right
here so after about one hour you'll lose
about one inch off the surface area of

that big a charred log about that big is
all it's going to be left
that's leaves about half an inch there
so this log will be completely gone in

now of course how hot the fire is the
type of wood you have whether it's a
hard wood versus a soft wood whether
it's dry versus green that will all
affect the time but rough estimate about
one inch per hour is what you're going
to lose so if you want to camp fire
that's going to last six hours that's
360 minutes okay one of these logs lasts
90 minutes so you need four of these
logs to last six hours on a one log fire
if you want a five log fire then you're
going to need 20 of these okay so just
for the fuel for your fire you'll need

right there and just top this sucker up

to keep it from rotting this is stuff
used in decks and a lot of exterior

your fire because the chemicals when
they burn can be very toxic so if you
find treated wood leave it alone have
seven logs that are averaging about
three inches in diameter so about an
hour and a half for each log building
about a four or five log fire so I have

than double what I probably need today

anything that has needles and sev leaves
